across.text: In vain, still awaiting service from bartender, allowing round character to push in?
across.explanation: POINTLESS(i.e. “in vain”). Solution is PINTLESS (i.e. “still awaiting service from bartender”) wrapped around or having O (i.e. “round character”) “push in”, like so: P(O)INTLESS.

across.text: Reservists accessing land from the East after deposing leader in country
across.explanation: QATAR(i.e. “country”). Solution is TA (i.e. “reservists”, specifically the Territorial Army) placed in or “accessing” IRAQ (i.e. “land”) once reversed (indicated by “from the East” – this being an across clue) and it’s first letter removed (indicated by “after deposing leader”), like so: QA(TA)R.

across.text: A doctor getting around predicament, gallant
across.explanation: ADMIRER(i.e. “gallant”). Solution is A and DR (a recognised abbreviation of “doctor”) wrapped “round” MIRE (i.e. “predicament”), like so: A-D(MIRE)R.

across.text: Odd bits removed from boiled rice, wrinkly
across.explanation: OLDIE(i.e. “wrinkly”). “Odd bits removed from” indicates the solution is derived from every other letter of BOILEDRICE.

across.text: Scene I love in theatrical piece
across.explanation: DIORAMA(i.e. “scene”). Solution is I and O (i.e. “love”, a zero score in tennis) both placed “in” DRAMA (i.e. “theatrical piece”), like so: D(I-O)RAMA.

across.text: Communicate anger initially in rage
across.explanation: GET ACROSS(i.e. “communicate”). Solution is A (i.e. “anger initially”, i.e. the first letter of “anger”) placed “in” GET CROSS (i.e. “rage”), like so: GET-(A)-CROSS.

across.text: Criminal, harmless beauty
across.explanation: SAFECRACKER(i.e. “criminal”). Solution is SAFE (i.e. “harmless”) followed by CRACKER (i.e. “beauty”).

across.text: One revealing all as tapestries unravelled, beginning on reconstruction
across.explanation: STRIPTEASER(i.e. “one revealing all”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “unravelled”) of TAPESTRIES followed by R (i.e. “beginning [letter] on reconstruction”), like so: STRIPTEASE-R.

across.text: Maestro in control, by the sound of it?
across.explanation: George FridericHANDEL(i.e. “maestro”). “By the sound of it” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of HANDLE (i.e. “control”).

across.text: Idyllic Scottish isle inspiring painting by Pissarro, originally
across.explanation: UNSPOILT(i.e. “idyllic”). Solution is UNST (i.e. “Scottish isle” – no, me neither) wrapped around or “inspiring” OIL (i.e. “painting”) once first placed after or “by” P (i.e. “Pissarro, originally”, i.e. the first letter of “Pissarro”), like so: UNS(P-OIL)T.

across.text: African really, African land
across.explanation: SOMALI(i.e. “African”). Solution is SO (i.e. “really”) followed by MALI (i.e. “African land”).

across.text: Avian selection from menu: that chicken?
across.explanation: NUTHATCH(i.e. bird or “avian”). “Selection from” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, like so: ME(NU THAT CH)ICKEN.

across.text: Note, I falter after passing motorway
across.explanation: DEMISEMIQUAVER(i.e. musical “note”). Solution is I and QUAVER (i.e. “falter”) both placed “after” DEMISE (i.e. “passing”) and M (a recognised abbreviation of “motorway”), like so: (DEMISE-M)-I-QUAVER.

across.text: Fermentation ingredient for instance fuelling still
across.explanation: YEAST(i.e. “fermentation ingredient”). Solution is AS (i.e. “for instance”) placed in or “fuelling” YET (i.e. “still”), like so: YE(AS)T.

across.text: Cub that is beside man
across.explanation: ROOKIE(i.e. “cub”, both referring to beginners). Solution is IE (i.e. “that is”) placed after or “beside” ROOK (i.e. “man” – sometimes chess pieces are referred to as men), like so: ROOK-IE.

across.text: Through taking leave, work at getting around puzzlement
across.explanation: PERPLEXITY(i.e. “puzzlement”). Solution is PER (i.e. “through”) followed by EXIT (i.e. “leave”) once placed in or “getting around” it PLY (i.e. “work at”), like so: PER-PL(EXIT)Y.

across.text: Quick way golden tortilla stuffed with last of cheddar
across.explanation: AUTOSTRADA(i.e. “quick way”, or a motorway in Italy). Solution is AU TOSTADA (i.e. “golden tortilla” – AU being the chemical symbol of gold) wrapped around or “stuffed with” R (i.e. “last [letter] of cheddar”), like so: AU-TOST(R)ADA. Chalk one to my Bradford’s here. I couldn’t think beyond taco for “tortilla”.

across.text: Month before king of France backed youth
across.explanation: JUNIOR(i.e. “youth”). Solution is JUN (i.e. “month”, short for June) followed by ROI (i.e. “king of France”, i.e. the French for “king”) once reversed (indicated by “backed”), like so: JUN-IOR.

across.text: In declaration, acquire land
across.explanation: GHANA(i.e. “land”). “In declaration” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of GARNER (i.e. “acquire”).

across.text: Blow that may have loosened dentures?
across.explanation: KICK IN THE TEETH(i.e. “blow”). Solution also satisfies the clue as a whole.

across.text: One couldn’t translate last part of poem, too long for translation
across.explanation: MONOGLOT(i.e. “one couldn’t translate” – a monoglot is someone who only knows one language). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “for translation”) of M (i.e. “last part of poem”, i.e. the last letter of “poem”) and TOO LONG.

across.text: Leading to end of obstruction, mostly healthy
across.explanation: LETHAL(i.e. “leading to end”). Solution is LET (i.e. “obstruction”, a variant meaning of the word we’ve seen in a couple of Jumbos) followed by HALE (i.e. “healthy”) once its last letter has been removed (indicated by “mostly”), like so: LET-HAL.

across.text: Animal’s oink best neglected
across.explanation: STEINBOK(i.e. “animal”). “Neglected” indicates anagram. Solution is an anagram of OINK BEST. A brute force of my Chambers was needed here.

across.text: Spring when fellow overheard?
across.explanation: GEYSER(i.e. “spring”). “When…overheard” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of GEEZER (i.e. “fellow”).

across.text: As, for example, planes run well during first minutes of flight?
across.explanation: ARBORESCENT(i.e. tree-like, or “as, for example, planes” – one of the definitions of “plane” is a kind of tree). Solution is R (a recognised abbreviation of “runs” used in some ball games) and BORE (i.e. “well”) both placed “during” ASCENT (i.e. “first minutes of flight”), like so: A(R-BORE)SCENT.

across.text: Token: give fourth out, banking first of cash
across.explanation: GIFT VOUCHER(i.e. “token”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “out”) of GIVE FOURTH wrapped around or “banking” C (i.e. “first [letter] of cash”), like so: GIFTVOU(C)HER.

across.text: Socially distancing in a fog
across.explanation: SPACED OUT. Solution satisfies “socially distancing” and mentally “in a fog”.

across.text: Girl wearing old fifties garment
across.explanation: OVERALL(i.e. “garment”). Solution is VERA (i.e. “girl’s” name) placed in or “wearing” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”) and LL (i.e. “fifties” – L being the Roman numeral for fifty), like so: O-(VERA)-LL. I rather liked this one.

across.text: Stout or plonk?
across.explanation: PLUMP. Solution satisfies “stout” or to “plonk”.

across.text: Doing a twirl in dress, it amuses artist
across.explanation: HenriMATISSE(i.e. “artist”). “In” indicates the solution has been hidden in the clue, while “doing a twirl” indicates the solution has been reversed, like so: DR(ESS IT AM)USES.

across.text: Sticky stuff, make error again?
across.explanation: RESIN(i.e. “sticky stuff”). When written as RE-SIN the solution also satisfies “make error again”.

across.text: Care when mate tumbles into river
across.explanation: TREATMENT(i.e. “care”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “tumbles”) of MATE placed “into” TRENT (i.e. “river”), like so: TRE(ATME)NT.

down.text: Churchgoing liberal missing company initially
down.explanation: PIOUS(i.e. “churchgoing”). Solution is COPIOUS (i.e. “liberal”) with the CO removed (indicated by “missing company” – CO being a recognised abbreviation of “company”).

down.text: What might be an incident I felt I messed up, having trapped organ
down.explanation: INDEFINITE ARTICLE(i.e. “what might be ‘an’”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “messed up”) of INCIDENT I FELT I wrapped around or “having trapped” EAR (i.e. “organ”), like so: INDEFINIT(EAR)TICLE.

down.text: Sweet nurse containing spillage of claret
down.explanation: TREACLE TART(i.e. “sweet”). Solution is TREAT (i.e. “nurse”) wrapped around or “containing” an anagram (indicated by “spillage of…”) of CLARET, like so: TREA(CLETAR)T.

down.text: Draw? Result needing attention
down.explanation: ENDEAR(i.e. to appeal to, or “draw”). Solution is END (i.e. “result”) followed by EAR (i.e. “attention”). I originally had this as LUSTRE, being an anagram of “result”. It didn’t help, as you can imagine.

down.text: Awful taking belt out to constrict part of leg
down.explanation: SHOCKING(i.e. “awful”). Solution is SING (i.e. “belt out”) wrapped around or “constricting” HOCK (i.e. “part of leg” in quadrupeds, apparently), like so: S(HOCK)ING.

down.text: As subversive on pier had, seaside picture
down.explanation: QUADROPHENIA(i.e. “seaside picture”. The film depicts the dust-ups between the mods and rockers on Brighton beach). Solution is QUA (i.e. “as” in Latin – an indicator would have been nice) followed by an anagram (indicated by “subversive”) of ON PIER HAD.

down.text: In conversation pour liquor, as unifying resolution
down.explanation: TEAM SPIRIT(i.e. “unifying resolution”). Solution is a homophone (indicated by “in conversation”) of TEEM (i.e. to “pour” – Chambers allows it with and without “down”) followed by SPIRIT (i.e. “liquor”).

down.text: I’ve got that man
down.explanation: ROGER. Solution satisfies “I’ve got that” in radio communications, and a “man’s” name.

down.text: Pour in an Italian drink for starters
down.explanation: ANTIPASTI(i.e. “starters”). Solution is TIP (i.e. “pour”, or to empty by tilting) placed “in” AN and ASTI (i.e. “Italian drink”), like so: AN-(TIP)-ASTI.

down.text: Audio equipment important, computer accessory unimportant
down.explanation: MICKEY MOUSE(i.e. “unimportant”). Solution is MIC (i.e. “audio equipment”, short for microphone) followed by KEY (i.e. “important”) and MOUSE (i.e. “computer accessory”).

down.text: Cultural identity courses discussed?
down.explanation: ROOTS(i.e. “cultural identity”). “Discussed” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of ROUTES (i.e. “courses”).

down.text: Place for break from teaching bible class
down.explanation: RESORT(i.e. “place for break”). Solution is RE (i.e. “teaching bible”, short for Religious Education) followed by SORT (i.e. “class”).

down.text: Something up sleeve, natural killer initially charging money for mischief
down.explanation: HANKY-PANKY(i.e. “mischief”). Solution is HANKY (i.e. “something up sleeve” – if you do this, kindly keep away from me) followed by N and K (i.e. “natural killer initially”, i.e. the first letters of “natural” and “killer”) once both placed in or “charging” PAY (i.e. “money”), like so: HANKY-PA(N-K)Y.

down.text: Unusual instrument just spinning in gossamer
down.explanation: THEREMIN(i.e. “unusual instrument”). Solution is MERE (i.e. “just”) reversed (indicated by “spinning”) and placed “in” THIN (i.e. “gossamer” – can be used as an adjective for light and flimsy), like so: TH(EREM)IN.

down.text: Be vulnerable to damage by stick – as might be tomato plant?
down.explanation: LIVE IN A GLASS HOUSE. Solution satisfies “be vulnerable to damage” and “as might be tomato plant”. “By stick” feels superfluous, so I might not have this completely right.

down.text: Recorder, one making music?
down.explanation: SCORER. Solution satisfies “recorder”, or one keeping score, and, playfully, “one making music”.

down.text: Common sense to carry weight under horse
down.explanation: GREY MATTER(i.e. “common sense”). Solution is MATTER (i.e. “weight”) placed after or “under” – this being a down clue – GREY (i.e. a kind of “horse”).

down.text: My nutritional value
down.explanation: GOODNESS. Solution satisfies the exclamatory “my” and “nutritional value”.

down.text: Copy the sixth of Henry’s books
down.explanation: PARROT(i.e. “copy”). Solution is Catherine PARR (i.e. “the sixth of Henry’s”, referring to the wives of Henry VIII) followed by OT (i.e. “books”, specifically the Old Testament of The Bible).

down.text: Placing coin, there’s a hole in it
down.explanation: PUTTING GREEN(i.e. “there’s a hole in it”). Solution is PUTTING (i.e. “placing”) followed by GREEN (i.e. “coin” – green is slang for money, though I would argue it’s really more to do with folding money than for coins).

down.text: Little bits present in mess tin, gone off
down.explanation: SMITHEREENS(i.e. “little bits”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “gone off”) of MESS TIN wrapped around or having “in” HERE (i.e. “present”), like so: SMIT(HERE)ENS.

down.text: Entertainer on hand?
down.explanation: GLOVE PUPPET. Solution satisfies the clue as a whole.

down.text: Cryptic inspected, filled with old tricks
down.explanation: DECEPTIONS(i.e. “tricks”). Solution is an anagram (indicated by “cryptic”) of INSPECTED wrapped around or “filled with” O (a recognised abbreviation of “old”), like so: DECEPTI(O)NS.

down.text: Concertina reflecting instrument?
down.explanation: TELESCOPE(i.e. “reflecting instrument”). Sorry, but I really don’t think a concertina and a telescopic action are the same thing. Fold back and forth along a strip of paper and you get a concertina effect. A telescope, meanwhile, is “to collapse part in part”(Chambers), like an old school radio aerial. There’ll no doubt be some dictionary that bails the setter out, but this still feels jarringly wrong to me.

down.text: Style in Versailles, period trousers unfashionable after revolution
down.explanation: BOUFFANT(i.e. “style in Versailles”). Solution is BOUT (i.e. spell or “period”) wrapped around or “trousering” NAFF (i.e. “unfashionable”) once reversed (indicated by “after revolution”), like so: BOU(FFAN)T. The clue was very nicely worked, but utterly evil to be given only the even letters to work with.

down.text: Reportedly fine coach
down.explanation: HANSOM(i.e. “coach”). “Reportedly” indicates homophone. Solution is a homophone of HANDSOME (i.e. “fine”).

down.text: Sophisticated Soviet letter, every other part redacted
down.explanation: SVELTE(i.e. “sophisticated” – another not really backed up by my Chambers, but there’s probably a looser dictionary out there that allows it. Either way, I still disagree). “Every other part redacted” indicates the solution is derived by taking every other letter ofSOVIETLETTER.

down.text: Devil, since secured by stake
down.explanation: BEAST(i.e. “devil”). Solution is AS (i.e. “since” or because of) placed in or “secured by” BET (i.e. “stake”), like so: BE(AS)T.

down.text: Key – what to do with it?
down.explanation: ENTER. Solution satisfies “key” on a computer keyboard, and also the clue as a whole.

down.text: Again, plant that’s lush coming up
down.explanation: REPOT(i.e. “again, plant”). Solution is TOPER (i.e. “lush” or drunk) reversed (indicated by “coming up” – this being a down clue).
